I don't know, probably not! It just seems to me that in spirit, although I accept their "popiness" Blondie's roots - or certainly the stuff I'm familiar with - seems to be more disco than pop.
And pop-punk, as far as I'm concerned, is a very different animal to what Blondie were - I mean, as others have said, the Ramones played pop standards, really, really quickly, and it's not hugely difficult to draw lines from them to NOFX to Offspring to Blink etc. If anything, you'd argue they were kind of more in keeping (musically) with the original punk, and it's the likes of say, At The Drive-In or Refused who are much closer to metal, arguably, than they are punk. At least to my ears.

possibly, but in normal circumstances, the (incoming) party leader would have been (a) elected on the party manifesto and (b) not be dealing with something both as divisive potentially catastrophic as Brexit; it's not like the Tory manifesto included what they'd do in the event of a vote to leave....
